awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometer to Enhance Undergraduate Research and Education in South Florida
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemical Instrumentation (CRIF) programs.   Professor Gregory McManus from Florida Gulf Coast University and colleagues Arsalan Mirjafari, Gregory Boyce, Daniel Paull and Xiaofei Zhang are acquiring a single crystal X-ray diffractometer. A diffractometer is a powerful tool used to determine the detailed structures of crystalline chemical compounds. X-rays are passed through a crystal of interest and a diffraction pattern is produced. The pattern is analyzed to obtain the microscopic structure, that is, the distances and angles between atoms in the material.  This structural data provides insight on the properties and possible uses of materials.  The researchers are investigating materials that can be used to store gases, such as methane or hydrogen for fuel applications.  Another investigation focuses on electrode materials for energy storage devices such as the lithium ion battery.   The diffractometer supports a network of chemistry faculty committed to undergraduate research and education in south Florida including: Florida Gulf Coast University, Florida Southern University, New College of Florida, Ave Maria University, St. Thomas University and Barry University.  The instrument is used to train undergraduate students in research.  The instrument is also used in lecture and laboratory courses preparing students for the modern workforce.

The acquisition of a single crystal x-ray diffractometer at Florida Gulf Coast University is used to support a wide variety of research projects including the synthesis of metal-organic materials for gas adsorption applications and the development of low-melting ionic liquids with high crystallinity which can be used as solvents in organic synthesis and separations.  Metal-organic framework systems are being studied for possible development as lithium-ion battery electrode materials.  The diffractometer is used to investigate the structure of palladium catalysts for possible use in synthesizing bioactive natural products.  Serpentine, a silicate mineral with three different types of crystals called polymorphs, is under study as a material for mineral-carbon dioxide sequestration. The diffractometer is used in studies to identify which polymorph is present in various samples.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2019, Florida Gulf Coast University (FGCU), a primary undergraduate institution, was funded through the NSF Major Research Instrumentation Program (Award # CHE-1919785) to acquire a single crystal X-ray diffractometer (SC-XRD) to support the research needs of faculty and undergraduate students. The SC-XRD instrument has had a significant impact on the quality of undergraduate research at FGCU. Since the instrument was installed in 2020, the PI, four co-PIs, one senior personnel, newly hired faculty, various external collaborators, and many undergraduate research students have collected over 380 datasets which lead to the structural determination of hundreds of crystal samples. Over the past three years, 11 publications with undergraduate coauthors were produced directly from the data generated from this project.

Having access to such a sophisticated instrument significantly increased undergraduate participation and retention. Many of the undergraduate research students involved with this project were first generation college students from underrepresented minority groups in STEM. Having experience with SC-XRD instrumentation made them more competitive for graduate programs. The undergraduate students who have received training from the research groups of PI/coPI have matriculated into the chemistry graduate programs of top-tier institutions including Northwestern University, Boston University, Johns Hopkins University, North Carolina State University, and the University of South Carolina.

All recent FGCU chemistry and biochemistry graduates were exposed to the SC-XRD instrument through a course-based undergraduate research experience in their required upper-level Inorganic Chemistry lecture/lab course. This educational research project was presented at an annual meeting of the American Crystallographic Association. An upper-level elective course, X-ray Analysis, was designed and offered by the PI in the spring of 2022. The students in this class were able to grow their own crystals and gain hands-on experience using the SC-XRD instrument.

In fall 2019, FGCU launched a new Bachelor of Science in Environmental Geology degree program. Through this project the students in Mineralogy & Petrology were able to participate in a week-long activity focused on crystallography and they were able to mount and collect data on various mineral samples. This activity was developed into a peer-reviewed teaching assignment and published with the Science Education Resource Center (SERC). Additionally, students involved with a NSF-GP-EXTRA grant (# 1911476) were provided with an immersive two-week summer training where they were able to collaborate with this NSF-MRI grant and gain first-hand experience collecting data, determining units, and solving crystal structures for various mineral samples. Introducing these students to advanced instrumentation like the SC-XRD can increase their likelihood of getting involved in undergraduate research and increase their retention in STEM degree programs.

This project provided access to SC-XRD instrumentation to chemistry faculty/students from other primarily undergraduate institutions in southwest Florida. In total approximately 150 datasets were collected involving collaborators from Ave Marie University and Florida Southern College.
